narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A lot of measure theory, and a lot of probability. This is essentially an advanced analysis class, nothing like MATH 241 or any classic S&DS class.
Measure theory, Lebesgue integration, independence, conditioning, martingales

measure theory and integration; the Lebesgue integral; probability distributions; densities and the RadonNikodym theorem; product spaces and independence; conditioning, laws of large numbers; convergence in distribution; characteristic functions; central limit theorems; martingales; large deviations

Topics including sigma algebras, measureability, probability spaces, independence, convolutions, conditioning, martingales.

Gained a stronger foundation in probability such that papers are fairly accessible.

The main topics covered are measure-theoretic probability, law of large numbers, conditioning, central limit theorem, and martingales. I gained a solid understanding about fundamental arguments used throughout measure theory and analysis.
I learned about measure-theoretic probability as well as parts of a research paper.
I learnt rigourous probability and lots of fun ways to apply the language of measure-theoretic probability.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strength(s): covers A LOT of material. Your math/probability knowledge will definitely improve. Also, problem sets were graded fairly (we were only graded on those and a final paper)
weakness: sometimes the problem sets go overboard, so you often have to learn things on your own accord.

Strengths: format of the course (heavily-weighed psets and a paper with no exams) was a wonderful change of pace, and lectures were really good. Sekhar's lovely. the paper was really open-ended and made me focus on something entirely new. 

Weaknesses: the problem sets were the main weakness. I felt very disengaged with the course and the p-sets were the majority of the reason why. they were not very motivating and did not really relate to the stuff we were learning in class, so I could get through them without much trouble despite not fully making the effort to understand the lectures (all I had to do was look up the definitions in the uploaded lecture sheets). I like the no-exam format, but without engaging, difficult p-sets, the result is just that students won't ever internalize the material since they won't ever be evaluated on their understanding. I wish the problems themselves were more interesting. they were a little too generic (e.g., "prove this generic measure that's clearly a measure is a measure", "prove this type of basic function is measureable", rather than "work with this specific cool measure," "use this stuff to find the probability of ____"). Martingales in particular have some really cool examples but only generic results came up on the psets. This is coming from a pure math major.

Sekhar is excellent at breaking down complicated, rigorous proofs into understandable steps. He also did a great job of pointing out common arguments that are used throughout the course. I would have appreciated it if he slowed down when presenting new definitions and theorems, since many of them are heavy in notation and difficult to parse upon learning them for the first time.

This course needs consistent notation, LaTeX'ed notes, slowed down lectures, and office hours at reasonable times. The professor's office hours were effectively meaningless since they were held right after a PSet was due and right before the next one was released. Warning: don't go into this class without having taken 305 or a real analysis course, because I didn't and paid the price. The professor goes mad fast and expects you to understand things immediately, else you have to figure it out yourself.

The problem sets reinforced the problems well. Sekhar's explanations were really clear and complemented the textbook. I felt like we could have done some more applications that really let us see the power of measures.  We didn't learn char functions, which made me a bit sad.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: the no exam decision was super helpful. I learned enough from just the lectures and problem sets.
This class simply needs a set of organized notes written in LaTeX with consistent notation.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Just make sure you have math background at the level of one analysis class (or something like that). I guess also having some prior knowledge in probability would also be helpful.

It really depends on the student. If they know a bit of measure theory and probability and want to learn more, sure. Sekhar is a fantastic lecturer and a great guy, and the format of the course is a really nice change of pace from most of the classes in math and stats, since we had no exams, but had a final paper. However, the material was often really dry, and there were very few fun examples on the problems sets and in lecture, so especially for a student like me who has only taken measure theory (with little to no stats/probability background), the results felt very unmotivated. 

I would not recommend the class to anyone who doesn't have experience with proof-writing and at least one analysis or measure theory class.

Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone interested in developing a rigorous understanding of measure-theoretic probability. It would help to have taken a measure theory course in the past, since this class goes at a very quick pace.

I would only recommend this course to another student if they have already taken real analysis and are willing to do a lot of individual studying/reading. Lectures won't be particularly productive since they are taught rather quickly.
Yes! Anyone in math should take this class, and so should stats majors who want to know why things really work. This is also a prereq for stats 410 which seems very fun.
